Hospitalization Record.Chief Complaint: Local redness, swelling, heat, and pain on the right forearm for 3 days.

Present Illness.Onset: 3 days ago, at home, suddenly noticed by mother
Present Illness.Main Symptoms: Localized redness, swelling, heat, and pain on the right forearm. The symptoms have progressively worsened over the last 3 days.
Present Illness.Diagnosis and Treatment History: Seen by a local physician, prescribed topical antibiotic ointment with no significant relief
Present Illness.General Condition Changes: Mental state normal, no changes in sleep, appetite good, normal urination and defecation, no weight change

Personal History.Living Habits: Regular attendance at school, balanced diet
Personal History.Occupation and Working Conditions: Student, no exposure to industrial toxins or hazardous working conditions
Personal History.Exposure History: No exposure to industrial toxins, dust, radioactive substances

Marital and Family History.Family History: Father (healthy), Mother (healthy), no siblings, no known family history of skin infections or genetic disorders

Systematic Examination.Skin: Erythema, heat, swelling, and tenderness over the right forearm, approximately 2 cm diameter
Systematic Examination.Chest: No abnormalities in thorax, lungs clear, heart sounds normal, no murmurs
Systematic Examination.Limbs: Normal mobility, aside from affected right forearm

Hospitalization Record.Auxiliary Examination: Complete Blood Count (CBC) showed mild leukocytosis, no other significant findings
Hospitalization Record.Diagnostic Basis: Based on clinical presentation, presence of localized infection, erythema, and tenderness, supported by CBC findings
Hospitalization Record.Differential Diagnosis: Carbuncle (no multiple purulent plugs seen), Folliculitis (lacks purulent plugs), Infected sebaceous cyst (more deeply located), Acne with mild infection (presenting differently)

Post-Admission Course Records.First Course Record: Furuncle diagnosed based on clinical presentation. Plan: Topical and systemic antibiotics, warm compresses, and pain management. Monitor progress over the next 24 hours.
Post-Admission Course Records.Daily Course Records: Day 1: Slight reduction in swelling, patient reports less pain. Continue current plan.
Post-Admission Course Records.Senior Physician Rounds Records: Day 2: Reviewed by Dr. Smith. Noted mild improvement, continue current therapy, plan for reassessment in 24 hours.
Post-Admission Course Records.Handover Records: Patient improving, continue with current management, reassess in rounds tomorrow.
Post-Admission Course Records.Stage Summary: Not applicable, early in treatment phase
Post-Admission Course Records.Consultation Records: Dermatology consult on Day 2, confirmed furuncle diagnosis

Medical Orders.Long-term Orders: Topical antibiotics (Mupirocin ointment) applied to affected area twice daily; Oral antibiotics (Cephalexin 250 mg) three times daily for 7 days
Medical Orders.Temporary Orders: Warm compresses applied to the affected area for 15 minutes, four times daily; Acetaminophen 10 mg/kg for pain as needed

Hospitalization Record.Temperature Chart: 37°C, Pulse: 90 bpm, Respiration: 20 breaths/min, BP: 100/60 mmHg on admission

Diseases of the Skin and Subcutaneous Ti.Name: Furuncle
Diseases of the Skin and Subcutaneous Ti.Symptoms: Superficial skin infection by fire poison, local redness, swelling, heat, and pain, acute suppuration
Diseases of the Skin and Subcutaneous Ti.Differential Diagnosis: Carbuncle (with multiple honeycomb-like purulent plugs on the surface), folliculitis (similar to a furuncle but without purulent plugs), infected sebaceous cyst, acne with mild infection
